The argument presented by the university president is that if they do not increase their enrollment, they will be forced to reduce spending next year, which will negatively impact the quality of education they provide. Therefore, the conclusion of the argument is that the university must market its programs more aggressively to increase its enrollment.

Option B is also incorrect because it assumes that the university will not need to reduce spending next year if it increases its enrollment, which is not the argument made by the university president. Option D is incorrect because it assumes that the university will not maintain the quality of the education it provides if it reduces spending next year, which is not the argument made by the university president. Option E is incorrect because it assumes that the university will not need to reduce spending next year if it markets its programs more aggressively, which is not the argument made by the university president.

Therefore, the correct answer is option C: The university will increase its enrollment if it markets its programs more aggressively.
